data.title: Feel My Hartbeat
data.text:
Guess WHoâ€™s Back?

I recently decided to start updating this blog again. When I did it regularly, it gave me so much joy. My last post was on Prodigyâ€™s passing. That was 6 years ago. So much has changed in my life since then. Iâ€™m a Registered Nurse now and I love what I do. I keep to myself these days though, so I donâ€™t get to have meaningful discourse with others about the music and things that I love. So guess what? Iâ€™m going to do it right here!

A couple of days ago, I came across this fire EP by Curren$y and Harry Fraud called â€œVices.â€ It was actually Spotify that suggested it to me and I was not mad that I gave it a listen. I am low key obsessed with it now actually.

Curren$y has a go-to aesthetic, and over the years he has fleshed it out on various projects. I have thoroughly enjoyed the ones helmed by Harry Fraud. And this one is no different. â€˜Vicesâ€™ has an 80â€™s, Miami Vice feel to it and I absolutely love it. The first track is a jubilant introduction to the EPâ€™s subject matterâ€“ cigarette boots used for drug trade in the Miami Harbor. Following the first track is â€œBlack Point Boat Launchâ€ which has a laid back, velvety smooth vibe to it.

But the stand out tracks to me are â€œStingray (feat. Benny The Butcher)â€ and â€œMarcus Camby (feat. Jim Jones & Tommy Wright III). When I tell you these tracks have presence, they undeniably do! The beat on â€œStingrayâ€ is top tier and has this impressive wailing lifted from the sampled track. I would love to hear what song was sampled. Bennyâ€™s verse is great! I love when he is featured on tracks because he NEVER slouches and his verses are always memorable. My only complaint was that this one was too short. It clocks in at only 2:07. â€œMarcus Cambyâ€ is incredibly satisfying. I really enjoy listening to it. It feels very lush and layered. Jim Jones spits a dope verse. Heâ€™s so consistent and versatile. Comfortable on any track. I could listen to this one on repeat for a very long time.

I almost forgot about â€œMarble Columns (feat Larry June).â€ Another impressive beat featuring a hypnotic saxophone riff accompanied by the most soulful banging drums. I love listening to this in my car because the drums sound incredible! Larry June isnâ€™t a rapper Iâ€™ve listened to recently but I did like his verse. I know he also has an album out produced by The Alchemist. Iâ€™m gonna give it a serious listen.

Iâ€™m glad Curren$y continues to explore this concept and I am so grateful for Harry Fraud. He is fast becoming to me what the Alchemist is! GOAT status!

RIP Prodigy!

â€œEsoteric knowledge and Iâ€™m criminal minded. A ladyâ€™s wet dream and the devilâ€™s worst nightmare.â€ â€“ â€œDeath Sentenceâ€ featuring Roc Marciano â€” â€˜Albert Einstein.â€™

I found out about Prodigyâ€™s passing after scrolling through a blog I visit often â€” which is weird because Twitter is usually where I find out someone died. When I came to the post, I stared at the title incredulously, immediately overtaken by a wave of sadness. Not P! He was in the upper echelon of rappers. His voice and style were my favorite things about him. His â€˜Albert Einsteinâ€™ LP is the project of his that I play the most. He was just so dope. Iâ€™m so tired of all the greats leaving us. First Sean Price a couple years ago, and now this. Iâ€™m deeply saddened and will miss him dearly.

When Bae Disappoints: Do Better Freddie!

Itâ€™s no secret that I love Freddie Gibbs. Ever since stumbling across â€˜Cold Day in Hellâ€™ and â€˜Baby Face Killaâ€™ some years ago after many a conversation on Twitter, Iâ€™ve been a die hard fan. But these days my love affair with Freddie has cooled some. I never thought this would ever happen, but it has. He released a new album this April and the album cover totally rubbed me the wrong way. I get that heâ€™s back home after his horrendous ordeal over in Europe, but I was a little perplexed and slightly enraged when I first saw his album artwork for his new album, â€˜You Only Live 2wice.â€™

I would post it here but I dislike the image so much that I donâ€™t want to display it so prominently on here. Basically, he has taken the scene pictured below, and made it his own by inserting himself where Jesus is shown and adding in pictures of his crew and half naked women where the disciples appear.

I had a really strong reaction to it when I first saw it on Spotify. My excitement at the fact that heâ€™d released new music quickly faded when I took in the album artwork. My first thought was, â€œThis is blasphemy,â€ and I was so disappointed that Freddie felt the need to go this route. Certain things are sacred and should not be tampered with, especially just for the purpose of selling music. I definitely think he went too far this time and I stopped listening to his music for almost a month because I believe in Jesus Christ and I feel something as meaningful and sacred as a depiction of his ascension into heaven should not be taken so lightly or desecrated so casually. Shame on you Freddie Gibbs. I know you thought you were just expressing yourself through art, but why couldnâ€™t you have picked another scene to recreate? Why purport yourself as Jesus? Thatâ€™s going way too far and I do not find it amusing at all.

The thing isâ€¦ I love Freddieâ€™s music. Well, everything heâ€™s released up until this latest album. I went to see him in Boston last year and the show was spectacular! And to cap things off, I was able to go on stage and give him a hug. The whole thing was surreal and I was so glad I went to see him in Boston. About four days ago, I decided Iâ€™d drop my ban on his music. I really wanted to hear â€œWhite Rangeâ€ so I played this Spotify playlist I made of all of my favorite songs of his as I was driving home from work. It was so satisfying. As I heard the songs, I realized how much Iâ€™d missed listening to his music. I tried listening to â€˜You Only Live 2Wiceâ€™ today but I just couldnâ€™t get into it. I felt weird playing it and I realized that thereâ€™s only one track on the album that I really dig. Itâ€™s called â€œAmnesiaâ€ and the beat is phenomenal. I added it to my playlist, and thatâ€™s probably the only song Iâ€™ll listen to on that project. I canâ€™t wait until the project with MadLib is liberated!

In closing, Iâ€™ll always be a fan of Freddie Gibbsâ€“ but that doesnâ€™t mean I condone everything he does. When news broke last year about the rape charges, I was crushed. Not Freddie! I didnâ€™t think he was capable of doing that. I was so relieved when he was exonerated. Thereâ€™s a program on VICE TV where he speaks with a therapist and describes being placed in a cell with other prisoners that had swastika tattoos while he was imprisoned in France. He told the man interviewing him that he didnâ€™t deserve that, and my heart went out to him. No black man deserves that. I was thrilled when he was released. Something about his music really appeals to me. Iâ€™m always happy when I find an artist that I really connect with. It didnâ€™t hurt that he was cool AF when I went to his show either.

I really wish I could ask him what he was thinking with this album artwork though. I have yet to read any articles online about it, but Iâ€™m going to do some research. I really want to know what he was trying to achieve by doing this.

But in the meantime, Iâ€™ll still be over here being a fan and listening to my playlist until he releases something newâ€“preferably with album artwork that doesnâ€™t depict anymore religious scenes. Iâ€™m good on that, thanks.

Surprise, Surpriseâ€¦

Kobe plays his last game tonight against the Utah Jazz. So I thought it was fitting to re-up this post I did about him 6 years ago, when I decided that I didnâ€™t want to hate him anymore. Love you Kobe! All the best to you and best wishes for a prosperous future!

Feel My Hartbeat

I like Kobe Bryant. I never thought those four words would ever come out of my mouth, but the impossible has happened. I decided a few weeks ago to end the constant hatred for him, and instead replace it with love.Iâ€™ve finally realized that there is something very special about him. I know Iâ€™m extremely late but Iâ€™m finally able to see that.

Plus hating on him is getting old. And while hating, I couldnâ€™t deny he was goodâ€¦really good. Iâ€™d watch his heroics silently cursing him but all the while marveling at his undeniable skill. All of my, â€œOoh I hate himâ€ barbs are useless now, because I donâ€™t hate him at all. I admire him and everything heâ€™s been able to accomplish. I adore the way he is with his daughters whenever the media shows him in an intimate moment with his family.

â€“104 victory against theâ€¦

View original post 51 more words

New SMOKE DZA!!!! (He Has Risen)

One of the best things ever in life is unexpected new music from a favorite artist.

I was using Spotify, as I am most days, because I had this deep urge to hear Smoke DZAâ€™s first album. Heâ€™s totally become one of my favorite lyricists recently. (His swag is untouchable!)

My heart jumped when I noticed , â€œHe Has Risen,â€ which was released a few weeks ago on March 4, on his profile page.

Continue reading â€œNew SMOKE DZA!!!! (He Has Risen)â€ â†’

Four Albums You Should Listen to, If you havenâ€™t

Here is some music that Iâ€™ve been playing heavily lately. It isnâ€™t especially current, or what is popular right now, but Iâ€™ve found that Iâ€™m happiest when I bypass whatever is on the radio and do my own thing.

Starting things off is â€˜Charleneâ€™ by R&B veteran, Tweet.

Continue reading â€œFour Albums You Should Listen to, If you havenâ€™tâ€ â†’

I Didnâ€™t Get Futureâ€™s Appeal

Why the excitement?

Iâ€™ve been trying to listen to the entire Future album, â€˜EVOLâ€™ for a few weeks now, but I just canâ€™t get into it. As someone who has a discerning ear and decent taste in music, Iâ€™ve realized that Future Hendrix just isnâ€™t for me. And even though I am probably in the minority, itâ€™s safe to say that Iâ€™ll never be a fan.

I work with a guy who swears by Future. Heâ€™s in his mid twenties.

â€œYou gotta really listen to what he says,â€ he told me one day. I stared at him blankly. And then I told him that I did, and that I wasnâ€™t impressed.

If youâ€™re into bass-heavy Trap music, then heâ€™s the way to go. But if youâ€™re into music with more substance, avoid Future. Donâ€™t even waste your time trying to convince yourself that heâ€™s gifted.

â€˜EVOLâ€™ isnâ€™t a solid album. It sounds like sh*t compared to Freddie Gibbsâ€™,â€™Shadow of a Doubt.â€™ Gibbsâ€™ flow makes whatever Future was attempting sound retarded. I kept listening for him to rap something noteworthy or remotely profound, but it never happened. And that auto-tune he insists on using is really awful. His fans still eat up his simple, brainless, brand of rap. Iâ€™m fairly sure most of them were born in the 90â€™s, have questionable taste in music and refuse to listen to 80â€™s and 90â€™s rap, totally oblivious to what quality sounds like, and resistant to anything other than whatâ€™s popular now. My coworker definitely falls into this category. When I asked him if he ever listens to Jay-Z, NaS or â€˜Pac, he replied, â€œWhat for?â€ Really dude?

Iâ€™ve decided that Iâ€™m not jumping on the Future bandwagon just to remain current. I am not going to bother trying to listen to someone who mumbles nonsensical phrases in annoying monotone for longer than a few minutesâ€¦.if that. I tried being open minded, but I think Future is just a fad rapper and I canâ€™t wait until he fades into obscurity. #sorrynotsorry

Update:

Despite me being extra hard on Future, I have identified several tracks on â€˜EVOLâ€™ that I actually likeâ€¦namely â€œSeven Ringsâ€ and a couple others. I donâ€™t hate Future. I just didnâ€™t understand why there was so much hoopla surrounding him when I felt his music wasnâ€™t really that noteworthy. Iâ€™ve since gone back through his catalog and I must admit that I do enjoy his â€˜Honestâ€™ album. I guess with more time, he will grow on me. And I think I had such a strong reaction to this â€˜EVOLâ€™ album that first time because someone I now donâ€™t care for swears by Future. Passing all of that judgment probably wasnâ€™t the wisest thing to do, and I now see the error of my ways. Iâ€™ll let Future liveâ€¦.

The Sean Price Tribute at SOBs

Itâ€™s been a little over a week since I went to NYC to attend the tribute for Sean Price at SOBs on August 27, 2015. The show was amazing and I had a great time vibing to Sean Pâ€™s music and enjoying the performers who came through. Here are a few of the pictures that I took.

I also took a bunch of video but because I was so close to the speakers at the front of the stage, they donâ€™t have any sound. ğŸ˜¦

Continue reading â€œThe Sean Price Tribute at SOBsâ€ â†’

In Memoriam: Sean Price

I came across this Sean â€œPâ€ Memorial mix on YouTube earlier today. It clocks in at around 30-minutes and features some of his best, most innovative videos expertly blended into a heart-stirring retrospect. I watched this video in total awe, mesmerized by his commanding presence and astounding talent. What a complete and utter shame that he is gone. He will definitely not be forgotten.

This is a must see for any â€œPâ€ fan.

Props to DJ Irie for putting it together.

We Lost Another Great: Rest In Power Sean Price

Sean Price, aka Ruck (of Heltah Skeltah) passed away on August 8th 2015.

I had the chance to say hello to him before he performed at the 2007 Brooklyn Hip Hop Festival. His humility and willingness to interact with his fans blew me away. Iâ€™ll admit that over the years, I wasnâ€™t as diligent with keeping up with his projects as I have been with others, but I at least made it a point to download whatever mixtape he released (ie. â€˜Kimbo Priceâ€™).

Lately, I have this burning desire to hear his music. To catch up on what Iâ€™ve unintentionally missed over the years. Iâ€™ve been listening to his â€˜Mic Tysonâ€˜ LP over and over. It sounds better than I remember. The beats are well-crafted and satisfyingly robust; the perfect compliment to his razor sharp rhymes. Revisiting â€œMonkey Barzâ€ and his other albums again will be fun. And Iâ€™m waiting in anticipation to check out his latest effort, â€œSongs in the Key of Price,â€ which will be available on August 21st. He left behind a solid body of work.

Sean P was an exceedingly gifted lyricist and heâ€™ll be sorely missed. Not only by me, but also his industry comrades who had the utmost respect for him, and the countless lovers of his brand of gully east coast rap.

Itâ€™s a shame that the great ones receive all the accolades once theyâ€™re no longer here. He should have been way more celebrated when he was around to appreciate it.

R.I.P. Ruck.

-MM

Audio Dope: â€œDiamondsâ€ x Freddie Gibbs

I have a serious thing for Freddie Gibbs. I donâ€™t even know if â€œthingâ€ is the right word to describe it. Itâ€™s more like a really, really intense obsession. His music appeals to my inner thug so I squealed with delight when I discovered his â€˜Prontoâ€™ EP on Spotify last night. Iâ€™m a bit late though. It was released in early March. But you know what they say; better late than never! I had been searching for the â€œBFKâ€ video on Youtube because I need that visual sometimes. And then, I came across the audio for â€œDiamondsâ€, the third track on the EP. It has been on repeat since I heard it last nightâ€¦no lie. Iâ€™m probably on listen number 1000 by now. It really is that mesmerizing! DZA used the same sample for his â€œPersonal Partyâ€ track on â€˜Rolling Stonedâ€™ but this track utilizes it better! Experience the magnificence below.

I Like Taking Pictures: Ghost in red + Rakim too

â€œMedallions the size of dinner platesâ€¦..â€

Came across these while scrolling through my forgotten Flickr page the other day. This show was in November 2007 at Roseland Ballroom in NYC. Rakim also performed.

Notes on â€œMr Wonderfulâ€ -Action Bronsonâ€™s First Studio Album

Yes. This is about Action Bronson. And yes, I know that a few posts ago, I didnâ€™t mince words about about what a significant asshole I feel he was for making his â€œBrunchâ€ video, in which he nauseatingly glorifies violence against women with zero remorse. I am willing to admit that I may have gone a little too far condemning him. Iâ€™ve had some time to think about it, and thereâ€™s no denying his talent, which is why Iâ€™m lifting my ban on his music.

I have a confession to make. Even after writing that post, I was listening to his music copiouslyâ€¦ (The â€œSaab Storiesâ€ EP specifically.) I absolutely love â€˜Triple Back Flipâ€™ (produced by Harry Fraud). Despite my displeasure with Action Bronson, my excitement began building the moment I heard he was releasing his first LP this year. I was convinced that the release date was March 17th. You should have seen me joyfully typing the album title into the Spotify search screen only to be crushed when I realized I had another week of waiting. Lol. I was even seriously contemplating taking the three hour Amtrak ride to NYC on the 23rd for his album release party at SOBs. All of this from someone who once declared Action Bronson to be a cheap Ghostface imitator. Oh how the tables have turned.

Continue reading â€œNotes on â€œMr Wonderfulâ€ -Action Bronsonâ€™s First Studio Albumâ€ â†’

The Solution

You ever think you know what a word means, and then realize that the actual meaning of that word is totally not the meaning you had in mind? I decided today that I was going to start referring to myself as an â€œaudiophile.â€ I always thought it sounded cool and was a term used to describe someone completely obsessed with music and high quality sounding audio. To be on the safe side, I hit up google and saw this definition:

A person who is especially interested in high fidelity sound reproduction.

Well, ok then. Not quite what I was thinking. So maybe â€œmusic junkieâ€ is a better term to describe me. Supposedly it means a person who explores the many different genres of music; constantly listening, downloading,and researching new bands. Yes. This is me.

So being the music junkie that I am, I am constantly searching for ways to experience the best quality sound when I listen to the music I love at home. Iâ€™ve fallen in love with Bose audio over the years, but realized that Bose is better suited for classical music or live concert recordings than say, rap. I love my rap and hip hop and I love hearing a pounding bass line. I gotta have that bass.

Continue reading â€œThe Solutionâ€ â†’

Audio Dope: â€œMe, Liquor and Godâ€ by Night Beds

I decided I needed to mix things up a bit concerning my music preferences a couple of months ago. Being the creature of habit that I am, I usually listen to the same music day in and day out. I know you know what Iâ€™m talking about; pressing play, day after day on your go-to playlists with those â€œtried and trueâ€ tracks that you love but wonâ€™t admit to yourself that youâ€™re tired of. Yup.

On this particular day, I took to Spotify (which is probably my favorite thing ever) to discover something new. I came across an Indie playlist and heard, â€œMe, Liquor and Godâ€ by Night Beds. My life changed forever when I heard it. No freaking lie. And there hasnâ€™t been a day since that I havenâ€™t listened to it at least once!

I donâ€™t know much about Night Beds but I swear (on everything I love) that this track is PERFECTION; complete and utter flawlessness. Itâ€™s that type of song you think about when itâ€™s not playing. Iâ€™m convinced it has transportive qualities. The music is like velvet, and the lyrics are heartfelt and real. Thereâ€™s a lot more to be said about how great this song is, but Iâ€™ll spare you. Youâ€™re just going to have to take my word for it, and listen for yourself.

I am all the way hooked. Iâ€™m talking, â€˜playing it on repeat for hours and hours and hoursâ€™ hooked. Every time I listen to it, it feels like Iâ€™m hearing it for the first time and Iâ€™m not sure if Iâ€™ll ever get tired of it.

Night Beds has a new album out called â€˜Country Sleep.â€™ (pictured above)

â€˜Country Sleepâ€™ is on Spotify! Iâ€™ve listened to it a few times, and I really like it.

It doesnâ€™t include â€œMe, Liquor and Godâ€ but it contains plenty of other satisfying, super dope tracks.

Night Beds is in line to become my new St Vincent; that one band/singer whose music I take the time to research, slowly digest and savor because I connect with it strongly for some reason.

Give this track and the album a listen. I dare you not to like it!

-M

They Have My Heartâ€¦

Wonder what this says about me?

Hopefully, that I like talented beat makers.

Alchemistâ€™s beats always rub me the right way. Theyâ€™re always elegant, endlessly thoughtful and tinged with a sinister, haunting quality, which I live for. Basically, I really love his stuff.

Thereâ€™s isnâ€™t much to say about Dilla that hasnâ€™t already been said. He was amazing at crafting the most spine-tingling and wildly satisfying beatsâ€¦ever. My favorites are the tracks he did for Ghostfaceâ€™s â€˜Fishscaleâ€™, and of course the ones that compile his much-lauded, â€˜Donuts.â€™

Madlib won my heart a while ago with the DOOM assisted â€˜Mad Villainyâ€™, but when I heard Freddie Gibbâ€™s â€˜Pinataâ€™, my heart just opened up to him. His beats are not only innovative, but also very polished and distinguished.

Iâ€™ll always love MF DOOM and his 50 trillion aliases. He has a knack for crafting robust, vintage sounding, buss your shit open beats.

And 9th wonder is a skilled purveyor of all audio that is crack. I love his expansive discography and all that he has accomplished in his career so far.

Skibeatz and Harry Fraud have worked with some of my favorite rap newbies like Curren$y and Smoke DZA and made some beautiful music recently.

Which producers are your favorite?

Let me know in the comments.

-MM

Throwback: My 25 most played in 2011â€¦

Apparently I was really feeling weed rap when I took this screen grab in 2011. Curren$yâ€™s â€œPilot Talkâ€ album had me fixated. I found it perplexing that I connected so much with his music even though Iâ€™ve never smoked weed a day in my life. The album was phenomenal though, consisting of an innovative concept, intricate flows and sophisticated beats. There isnâ€™t much that was missing. Initially I found Curren$yâ€™s voice slightly irritating, but everything changed when I heard â€œKing Kong,â€ which weighs in at number 2 in my most played. That dangerous Ski beat was the reason I listened to it on repeat for days. Iâ€™d never heard a more satisfying beat and it still stops me in my tracks today.

I was also loving Smoke DZAâ€™s â€œGeorge Kush Da Buttonâ€ album. I didnâ€™t fully understand the title but it was a very satisfying listen. DZA has a distinct drawl and a swaggy persona that I ate right up. This album and itâ€™s accompanying videos cemented my desire to see him live in concert.

There are also a few tracks by N.E.R.D. in my most played too. Theyâ€™ll always be my favorite band. I loved that Nothing album.

2015 Update:

I no longer use iTunes for music. Instead I prefer Spotify but they donâ€™t do a most played. If they did, youâ€™d probably find lots of Ghostface Killah, Freddie Gibbs, Mobb Deep and Sean Price on there.

-MM

DOPE: Black Milkâ€™s, â€œIf Thereâ€™s a Hell Belowâ€

Released 10/28/14.

In a word: AMAZING!

Still digesting and Iâ€™m loving what Iâ€™m hearing.

-MM

Current fixation: St Vincent

Iâ€™ve been listening to a lot of St Vincent lately. I discovered her in 2012 and fell in love with her 3rd album entitled â€œStrange Mercy.â€™ Her real name is Annie Clark and sheâ€™s an excellent guitarist and a dope vocalist. I really dig her music, which can be classified as â€œindie popâ€ or â€œbaroque pop.â€ She released her 4th album, â€˜St Vincentâ€˜ last year. It also goes hard, but of her four albums, I like â€˜Strange Mercyâ€™ the best. The lyrics to her songs are sometimes very dark but always unexpected. I really like â€˜Strange Mercyâ€™ because it has a very lush sound that captivates after the first listen.

Hereâ€™s a video of Annie in 2011 performing â€˜Cruelâ€™, one of my favorites from her â€œStrange Mercyâ€ album at KCRW studios. This video is cool because you get to see her playing the guitar live. Itâ€™s obvious that she is a very skilled musician as well as a cool artist. She also sounds just like her tracks when she sings live. Enjoy!

And hereâ€™s a taste of what she sounds like now. This is audio of â€˜Prince Johnnyâ€™ from her self titled 4th album. I was obsessed with this song the first time I heard it. So freakinâ€™ dope!

Updated: Reviewing Ghostface Killahâ€™s discography

Ghostface Killah is my favorite artist and rapper of all time, and in the wake of attending my 7th concert, I decided to take a trip down memory lane to reflect on and review his extensive discography.

First up is:

Ironman (1996)

Continue reading â€œUpdated: Reviewing Ghostface Killahâ€™s discographyâ€ â†’

Really, Action Bronson?

Action Bronson, you almost had me. I was on the brink of being lured in by your sounds. I was about to fall hard for you. But then I saw that disgusting â€œBrunchâ€ video of yours on YouTube. You know the one where you hurl all sorts of profanities and insults at a dead girl and then dump her into the ocean after rolling her body into a rug. It was truly grotesque and removed any desire I may have had to get to know you better.

To be honest, I was looking to you to fill a void. My favorite rapper hasnâ€™t released new music in a while and you sound eerily like him. But hereâ€™s whatâ€™s obvious; you will never be Ghostface. I donâ€™t care how much you sound like him. He would never make a video disrespecting woman to the degree that you did. Not even at his lowest.

The â€œBrunchâ€ video really rubbed me the wrong way. I donâ€™t care if it was a metaphor or an over-exaggeration of a bad breakup, it was in poor taste.

Let me back up though. Let me not assume that everyone knows who Action Bronson is. Action Bronson is an American rapper from Flushing Queens who wasnâ€™t really on my radar until now. My step brother was a big fan of his and shared some of his music with me last year, namely â€˜Rare Chandeliers,â€™ produced by Alchemist and â€˜Well Done,â€™ produced by Statik Selektah. For some reason, I wasnâ€™t receptive to his music before. I recently thought I was ready to embrace it wholeheartedly, but the â€œBrunchâ€ video has me thinking otherwise. I get the whole artistic expression thing, but sometimes you can take it a little too far. Whatâ€™s unfortunate is that I was really starting to like his bold delivery and irreverent lyrics. I was even willing to look past the fact that lyrically heâ€™s a Ghostface clone. And his voice was just starting to excite me. Not to mention I was also digging the way he handled himself on beats by Alchemist. â€˜Rare Chandeliersâ€™ is dope. I canâ€™t front. Bronson rhymes the way I wish Ghostface still did. Butâ€¦ itâ€™s too late. Iâ€™ll never look at him the same ever again. I have no desire to get into his music anymore. Iâ€™m moving on. Iâ€™ll stick with the original. The End.

-MM

What Iâ€™m Listening to Right Now

I just made a dope little Spotify playlist from eight songs that appear on these two projects.

I hadnâ€™t listened to them both until recently and Iâ€™m not really sure why it took me so long to hear them. Anyway, these tracks that Iâ€™ve mentioned below go VERY hardâ€¦

1) â€œDeath Sentenceâ€ â€“ Prodigy x Alchemist feat. Roc Marcianoâ€“ from The Albert Einstein project

Prodigyâ€™s deep-voiced cadences complement the understated Alchemist beat perfectly. An assist from Roc Marciano ups the dopeness factor and makes this song a bonafide standout.

2) â€œDough Pildinâ€ â€“ Prodigy x Alchemist â€“ from The Albert Einstein project

This track has the type of Alchemist beat that I live for; subtle and beautifully crafted. Prodigy spits his usual philosophical braggadocio making this another win win.

3) â€œBreezeâ€ â€“ Prodigy x Alchemist â€“ from The Albert Einstein project

This is my favorite track on the â€˜Albert Einsteinâ€™ project. The beat is impossibly smooth and Pâ€™s flow is incredible. He effortlessly rides the beat and unloads quotable after quotable. I can picture myself lying on a beach somewhere warm listening to this. This track is laid back perfection.

4) â€œRaw Foreverâ€ â€“ Prodigy x Alchemist â€“ from The Albert Einstein project

I chose this track because I like the way the beat constantly changes up. This is a classic feel good track that leaves me happy after every listen.

5) â€œSay My Nameâ€ â€“ Prodigy x Alchemist â€“ from The Albert Einstein project

This beat sounds so amazing to me. Pâ€™s lyrics are first rate as usual. This is the kind of sonic gem that I could memorize word for word.

6) â€œTriple Backflipâ€ â€“ Action Bronson â€“ from â€˜Saab Storiesâ€™ produced by Harry Fraud

This song was my first real introduction to Action Bronson and I gotta say, I really liked it after that first listen. Harry Fraud is obviously no slouch in the production department. The beat sounds very opulent and inviting.

7) â€œThe Rockersâ€ â€“ Action Bronson feat. Wiz Khalifa â€“ from â€˜Saab Storiesâ€™ produced by Harry Fraud

I liked this beat as soon as I heard it. It sounds like it should be featured on a, â€œfor the ladiesâ€ type of track but Action Bronson eschews the formulaic subject matter and raps about something entirely different. And it works.

8) â€œSeven Series Tripletsâ€ â€“ Action Bronson feat. Prodigy and Raekwon â€“ from â€˜Saab Storiesâ€™ produced by Harry Fraud

The beat on this track reminds me of one Ghostface might have used on â€˜Fishscaleâ€™ or â€˜Bulletproof Walletsâ€™. It has a somber, appealing quality to it and the guest rappers Prodigy and Raekwon, really bring out the beauty of the beat.

Hartbeat Fave: Phyllis Hyman

Phyllis Hyman was an incredible singer-songwriter who was the epitome of elegance, confidence and style while she was alive. One of my favorite recordings by her is â€œComplete Meâ€ which appeared on her well received 1979 album, â€œYou Know How to Love Me.â€ I purchased this album on a whim around 2000, and Iâ€™ve never once regretted it.

She was a wildly talented artist and possessed a captivating voice imbued with quiet sophistication and a unique richness. She also never sang without copious amounts of passion and emotion. She will forever be one of my favorite singers. Following are some of my all-time images of her, as well as a YouTube video of â€œComplete Meâ€.

Good Reads

Iâ€™m reading again! When I was in school a month ago, it was difficult for me to read recreationally. But now that Iâ€™m out, itâ€™s on! Iâ€™ve recently been reading several books about Hip-Hop. Since I love it so much, I figured I should know more about its history.

I started with Bakari Kitwanaâ€™s â€œThe Hip Hop Generationâ€

It was a good read. Bakara Kitwana refers to the hip hop generation as those born between 1965 and 1984. It wasnâ€™t much of a history of Hip Hop as I had hoped but in it, he makes clear arguments about what has affected Black youth over the last twenty years and offers up solutions. I had bought this book years ago (maybe in 2003 or so) intending to read it right away but never did. It felt good to finally finish it.

After reading that book, I decided I wanted to read a history of Hip Hop, so I started Jeff Changâ€™s â€œCanâ€™t Stop Wonâ€™t Stop; A History of the Hip Hop Generationâ€.

I am really enjoying it so far. The author has a brilliant way with words and paints vivid pictures about Hip Hopâ€™s humble beginnings leading up to today. Itâ€™s the kind of book you donâ€™t want to put down because it is so riveting. Iâ€™m half way through it. I almost wish Kitwana had used the same language to write the â€œHip Hop Generationâ€ because Iâ€™m sure I would have enjoyed it more. But I guess the subject matter didnâ€™t really lend to that.

Next, I read M. K. Asanteâ€™s â€œItâ€™s Bigger than Hip Hop â€“ The Rise of Post Hip Hop Generationâ€

Iâ€™d been reading all about the â€œHip Hop Generationâ€ and wanted to read about the â€œPost Hip Hop Generationâ€ which follows as well. It was a decent book. The author is a young activist and is a professor at Morgan State. He â€œuses hip hop as a springboard for a larger discussion about the urgent social and political issues affecting the post-hip-hop generation, a new wave of youth searching for an understanding of itself outside the self-destructive, corporate hip-hop monopoly.â€ In it, he has an interview with Dead Prez. Iâ€™m supposing that he got the name of his book from their song. He also interviews Hip Hop itself. It was a well-written book and Iâ€™ll probably read it again.

And last but not least, I just finished John H McWhorterâ€™s, â€œAll About the Beat: Why Hip Hop Canâ€™t Save Black Americaâ€

I happened to come across this book while browsing for other books about Hip Hop online. Written in 2008, McWhorter asserts in this book that Hip Hop doesnâ€™t have the potential to foster a revolution of positive change in the lives of black people. I didnâ€™t know how to feel when I read this, especially when I had held the belief that hip-hop was so great and powerful and such a strong, prevailing force in my life. McWhorter smashes the claims that hip-hop is politically valuable because it delivers the only â€œrealâ€ portrayal of black society. He points out that hip-hop is, at its core, simply music, and takes issue with those who celebrate hip-hop as the beginning of a new civil rights program and inflate the lyrics. While reading, I found myself jotting down notes and agreeing with quite a bit of what he wrote. Yes, sermonizing rather than working on the problems is not the answer. We really do need to â€œtranslate hipness into action and activismâ€. It was short, but sweet. And it was refreshing to read a book written by someone on the other side of the argument. McWhorter dislikes the term â€œHip Hop Generationâ€ and thinks history is not on the side of revolution now. Some key notes:

â€“ â€œSnapping our necks to beats and rhymes will have no effect on what happens in the congressional chamberâ€

â€“ â€œThe seduction of rhythm is indeed much of why so many people entertain the prospect of a revolution based on rap music.â€

â€“ â€œRhythm is deeply seductive. Even babies like it.â€

-â€œBlack people need to get beyond the idea that something is true because it is expressed in infectious rhythm.â€

â€“ â€œThe idea that rhythm and inflection constitute coherent political insight worthy of extended attention is wrong.â€

â€“ â€œWords, sentences, logical connections, and constructive thought will be our salvation. Mysticism will not â€“ even if itâ€™s set to a great rhythm track.â€

-â€œThe beat is not truthâ€

-â€œIn being art, especially popular art, hip-hop is automatically disqualified from being meaningfully politicalâ€

-â€œAnyone who says hip-hop is dead is being theatrical and seeking attentionâ€

â€“ â€œA revolution does not consist solely of howling grievancesâ€

-â€œThe fact that our ancestors were brought here as slaves and endured Jim Crow does not arouse people anymore.â€

Now that I have a working knowledge of Hip Hop history, I think Iâ€™ll delve into Black history some more. Thereâ€™s a book that I had to read for an African Studies class at Drexel called â€œBlack Intellectualsâ€ by William M Banks that Iâ€™ve always wanted to re-read. And there is one on the Civil Rights Movement called â€œFreedom Bound â€“ A History of Americaâ€™s Civil Rights Movementâ€ by Robert Weisbrot that looks interesting as well. Following those, I will probably begin â€œWe Are Not What We Seem: Black Nationalism and Class Struggle in the American Centuryâ€ by Rod Bush. Reading is dope.

-MM

I enjoyed his â€˜Lincoln Way Nightsâ€™ mixtape and was thrilled when I came across this video for the â€œShop Remixâ€ today. Joe Budden: Master Storyteller?

Ok, so letâ€™s recap. We already know Nas, Big, Jay-Z and Ghostface top the Exceptional Story-teller list. (Wellâ€¦â€¦.mine atleast) But what about Joe Budden? Can we add him to the list too?

I asked myself these questions upon revisiting a track on his Mood Muzik 2 mixtape entitled, â€œThree Sides to a Storyâ€œ. On this particular track, Joe spins a riveting tale from three different perspectives.

In the first verse he describes the life of a young man, named Derek, whose life is riddled with drama. Derek is in and out of jail and lives a hard life and no matter what he does he always finds himself in a f*cked up situation. Derekâ€™s sister Sally is the focus of the second verse. She is molested by her motherâ€™s boyfriend but her big brother Derek is in jail, so he cannot help her. It is difficult to hear Joe recount her tale and even though it brings a bad feeling, you canâ€™t help but continue to listen. He uses simple language to paint a vivid picture of anguish, horror and sexual molestation.You can imagine what this girl must have gone through and envision the pain she must have endured. Joe uses just the right words to get his point across and transport you right to the scenes he so expertly describes. This is characteristic of an extremely effective story-teller.

The third perspective is the culmination of this sad story. It is told from the stepfather â€œBoâ€â€˜s perspective. I wont ruin it by telling you what happens but letâ€™s just say that the ending is not a happy one.

With this track Joe Budden proves he can hang with the big dogs. I was always aware of his talent for grittier, more street infused rhymes but he also has a knack for the quieter, true-to-life soliloquies as well. With that said, I definitely feel that Joe Budden belongs up there with Nas, Jay, Big and Ghostface as a â€œMaster story-tellerâ€. And yes Iâ€™m basing that off just this one song, and I hope he makes many more like it.

If you havenâ€™t heard the song, you can listen to it on good old YouTube!

Know anymore Joe Budden songs that are a better example of his excellent story telling ability? leave a comment!

RELATED POST: Whoâ€™s The Best Storyteller: Biggie, Jay-Z or NaS?

HARTBEAT FLASHBACK: VIDEO -Tupac â€œKeep ya Head Upâ€

You ever come across a song that you just have to stop and listen to whenever it comes onâ€¦.no matter what youâ€™re doing or where you are? Tupacâ€™s â€œKeep ya Head upâ€ is one of those songs for me.

This song started my love affair with Hip Hop in 1993. I remember seeing this video at age 12, four or five months after moving to this country from Jamaica. It had a profound impact on me and I fell in love with Tupac immediately after. This song had a very positive, wholesome message which did a lot to challenge what the grownups in my life claimed Hip Hop was all about and from that first viewing of the video, I was hooked. I began to listen to more Hip Hop and purchase his music as a result. I would soon realize that not all his music was as uplifting as â€œKeep ya Head upâ€œ, but I loved him just the same.

This song showed Tupacâ€™s softer side but before long I was introduced to the more volatile, angry side which I loved as well. Tupac always had an important message to share and I always tuned in to hear it. My mother hated him because he was always in the news (remember? and not in a good way) and I remember she hid my â€œDon Kiluminati:The Seven day Theoryâ€ and â€œR U Still Downâ€ cds because of this. It didnâ€™t matter to me though. I always found a way to replace them.

Tupac inhabits position #3 on my greatest emcees of all time list. His music will always appeal to me and this song will always be one of my special favorites. Hereâ€™s the video:

Bonus video if you read the restâ€¦.

The Ubiquitous Hip-Hop Accessory: The â€œJesus Pieceâ€

The â€œJesus pieceâ€ has long been regarded as one of Hip Hopâ€™s most beloved accoutrements.

It is an oversized platinum, gold or silver pendant, made in the likeness of Jesus, sometimes encrusted with diamonds and other gems . Worn on a heavy rope style chain, these pendants have been a staple of Hip Hop youth culture for nearly thirty years. (from Urban Dictionary.com)

I am not exactly certain who originated this popular adornment. Kanye West would probably argue that he made the â€œJesus pieceâ€ popular but I believe that the real honor should go to the Notorious BIG, who was seen wearing one in the popular image below.

â€œCubans with the Jesus Pieceâ€ â€“ The Notorious BIG (Hypnotize)

In recent years, rappers like Kanye West, Jay-Z and Kid Cudi have championed the â€˜Jesus Piece movementâ€™ by wearing these pendants embedded with colored and black diamonds and precious stones. Styles made from lighter wood have also been popularized by Kanye West, Jadakiss, LeBron James, Braylon Edwards and even Pau Gasol. Here is a Jesus Piece gallery with a few items ranging from beautiful to seriously hideous:

Kanyeâ€™s piece not, shining as brightly.There is something extremely gaudy about itâ€¦but hey, Iâ€™m not a famous rapper. What do I know?

Kanyeâ€™s Murakami Jesus Piece pictured aboveâ€¦(Pretty cool, eh?)

Jay-Zâ€™s is some sort of burnished metal.

The â€œall black everythingâ€ Jesus piece

Kid Cudiâ€™s looks exactly like Kanyeâ€™s. Maybe he borrowed it??

This one (above) is quite bizarre. Who would wear this?

More of the people who wear them

Whatâ€™s notable is that most times the wearer isnâ€™t even making a statement about any religious beliefs, just simply wearing one to be fashionable. And donâ€™t expect this trendy fashion statement to go anywhere anytime soon either. With the affordable wood version more accessible than the costly precious metal and stones version, these pendants will be around for years to comeâ€¦or as soon as this fad burns out. And of course fake Jesus pieces abound as well. With the â€œJesus Pieceâ€ branded as a classic, just like the cuban link chain now everyone can dress just like their favorite rapper or athleteâ€¦used to?

Just found this interesting pieceâ€¦. right here that claims the Jesus Piece is dead. But I donâ€™t think thatâ€™s necessarily true. I think itâ€™s a classic and classics never die. It might go into remission for a while. But it will not die.

And just in case you were wondering what the point of this post wasâ€¦.I just always wondered about Jesus Pieces and who wore them besides Kanye West. Apparently not too many people still do. My Google search was futile. I guess Kanye is now sole owner of this trend, but it looks like heâ€™s retired his Jesus Piece for this ridiculous hunk of metal. Oh wellâ€¦long live the Jesus piece!

Just for fun: Check out the dudes from â€˜Itâ€™s the Realâ€™ in â€œJews for Jesus Pieceâ€

My dilemmaâ€¦

So I just noticed today that Iâ€™ve been fixating on the same music as the years go by. I just checked out a post I did 3 years ago and Iâ€™m STILL listening to almost all the same songs I wrote about then, today. This has to stop

My taste in music hasnâ€™t really evolved at all in the past 10 years. I still like and listen to all the same old songs. The problem is that I havenâ€™t heard any new songs recently that have moved me. Maybe the production just isnâ€™t as good as it was in the past? I know one things for sure though. I canâ€™t keep listening to the same albums like â€œDiplomatic Immunityâ€ and â€œSupreme Clienteleâ€ all the damn time! I need some new music to become obsessed with!

Recently, I got excited listening to Wiz Khalifa. I liked his style and the beats he used on his â€œKush & Orange Juiceâ€ mixtape. I purchased his â€œDeal or No Dealâ€ album on iTunes and I listen to it a lot. This was my first attempt at staying current.

Now I want to check out Curren$y. Iâ€™m not 100% sold on him as an emcee though. I find his voiceâ€¦wellâ€¦a teeny tiny bit annoying, but I previewed the album (well, I heard all the 30 second clips of the album) and it sounds like something I might like. Going to buy it.

Before I go any furtherâ€¦I gave Fat Joeâ€™s â€œThe Darksideâ€ and Rick Rossâ€™ â€œTeflon Donâ€ a chance too but didnâ€™t come away with much. This was my second attempt at staying current. I liked â€œFree Masonâ€ and â€œMaybach Music 3â€ on â€˜Teflon Donâ€™ but nothing stood out to me on Fat Joeâ€™s album. And that is probably going to be it for me and mainstream Hip Hop for a while. I find the albums to be uninspired, boring and contrived. And then I have this thing about not listening to music if I donâ€™t like the artistâ€™s voiceâ€¦ which is why I avoid Lilâ€™ Wayne and TI like the plague. The only mainstream artists who Iâ€™ll pay any real attention to are Ghostface, Jay-Z, 50 Cent (well, most times), NaS, Kanye West and Mos Def . Iâ€™ve never gotten into Bun B even though Iâ€™m sure his album is very good. Itâ€™s just not my steez I guess. I may check it out though, just out of curiosity, just to hear what a Sourceâ€ 5 micâ€ album sounds like.

So I have a real dilemma. I just canâ€™t seem to come across a lot of good music that holds my attention lately.

Hoping that will change when I listen to or purchase these albums/mixtapes in the near future:

Distant Relatives â€“ Nas and Damian Marley (Canâ€™t believe I havenâ€™t heard this one yet!)

Big Picture â€“ Big L (Iâ€™ve never heard a Big L album. Guess that makes me a fake hip hop head)

Boy Meets World â€“ Fashawn (He has a good buzz right now. I want to hear what heâ€™s all about. But on second thought, Iâ€™m not really digging his voice. I have to see if I can get past that because there are some good beats on this album)

Fornever â€“ Murs + 9th Wonder ( Never heard a full Murs album before either. Would like to check this out) I always do the 30 second preview of each track before purchasing. Upon doing that I only liked 2 tracks: â€œVicky Veilâ€ and â€œI used to Love Her (Again)â€ which I purchased on iTunes.

Till the Casket Drops â€“ Clipse (I donâ€™t own a Clipse album. Would be nice to hear whether or not theyâ€™ve evolved.) Gave it a listen and I like it!! The beats are tight! Purchased!

Kimbo Price â€“ Sean Price (I like this guyâ€¦always have. Eager to hear this mixtape. Downloaded as of 8/28)

Double Barrel â€“ Marco Polo + Torae (This is another album Iâ€™ve been hearing about. But I will dismiss it if I donâ€™t like their rapping voices. Yesâ€¦I am surface like that)

Preface â€“ Elzhi ( I like Elzhi and I want to give this a listen)

Another Heist â€“ Camp Lo (Curiosity about whether this is good or not will make me listen to it)

Born Like This â€“ MF Doom (Not sure how new this is but I love all things Doom)

Shibuyaâ€“ Nicolay (not that familiar with Nicolay, but the title sounds cool so Iâ€™m game)

I am so desperate to add some quality new music to my iPod. Feel free to suggest some more albums I should listen toâ€¦Please and Thank you!
